0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

1.subquestion: Write down every term as either zero or some positive integer less than seven (exclusive), according to its congruence class modulo seven.

subanswer.text: Each term increases by five; thus they form pairs whose remainders add up to six ($1+2=3,$ etc.). There were thirty terms total, so half contribute nothing while the other fifty have remainders equal to three times their position in sequence divided by ten plus one ($\lfloor n/10\rfloor$), where floor means rounding towards negative infinity (\(\lfloor n/10\rfloor\) denotes how many groups of ten fit inside \(n\).): \[\begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline Position & Remainder \\ \hline k\text{(odd)} & \{\\[\frac{k}{2}+1\mod7\} \\ \hline k\text{(even)} & \{3\{k/10\}\mod7\} \\ \hline Total \;sum &= 3\;S_{25}+\underbrace{3*1}_{i=1}^{25}(3k/10)\equiv3*\frac {25*(25+1)*2*7}{4!}=\boxed{3} \pmod 7 . \end{array}\] The answer is $\{3\}$, which equals $[3]$. Note also that since $7^{2}-1=48<25\times 10=250,$ no residue repeats itself twice within any pairwise combination over those thirty integers – hence why I had trouble writing them without fractions..

ost_step.1: Notice that each term in the series is one more than a multiple of seven. Specifically, it takes nine terms until you reach back up to another multiple of seven ($1+9=10$, $19+8=27$, etc.). There are fourteen such sets of nine numbers within our range ($199 - 1)/9 + 1 = 14\text{sets}$, so let us first add them together using some math tricks involving triangular numbers. 0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Notice that each term in the sequence is congruent to either 1, 3, or -1 when taken modulo $7$, because adding multiples of 7 does not change the residue class under modulus $7$. For example, any odd multiple of $7$ such as $14k+7$, reduces to just $7 \equiv 0\pmod{7}$, so those terms don't contribute to our sum. Thus the problem simplifies to finding the sum $S=1+3+5-1-3-5+\dots+195+197+199$ which again takes alternating signs due to every other member being equivalent to zero mod $7$. Now notice how it would take us less work counting pairs since within each pair one value equals halfway around the clock compared to another; i.e., starting with ones side of midnight ($1$), ending up directly opposite at three o’clock (`+/- 2`) , going backwards along twelve hours until arriving back next day `$-\dfrac{N}{2}= -\dfrac{301}{2} \approx -151` . However note however nowhere

0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

1.subquestion: Observe that every third term starting at $1$ (i.e., terms whose index leaves a remainder of $1$ upon division by $3$) sums up to multiples of which prime?

subanswer.text: Every three consecutive integers form an arithmetic sequence where the middle term ($k+1$) equals their average. Hence they sum to $3(k+1)$. 0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

ost_step.1: Notice that each term in the series is one more than a multiple of seven. Specifically, it takes nine terms until you reach back up to another multiple of seven ($1+9=10$, $19+8=27$, etc.). There are fourteen such sets of nine numbers within our range ($199 - 1)/9 + 1 = 14\text{sets}$, so let us first add them together using some math tricks involving triangular numbers. Each set adds ninth multiples plus twelve extra odd integers; both sums yield perfect squares! Thus $$S_{set}={9}^2+{12}(2*1)+...+ {9}^2+{12}(2*14)$$which reduces further into$$ S_{total}=14({9}^2+{12}(2)(15)).$$Now plugging everything in yields $$\\[1ex] \\begin{aligned}\quad&{14}[\,(81)\,+\,({\color{Red}12})(2)(\,\color{OliveGreen}{\bcancel{15}}\,\,)\,]=14[(96){\cdot}\,\color{CadetBlue}{\left(\displaystyle

Indeed $\;\overline{192}+7 =\color{#FF4F00}{199}\:$ exactly matches the last digit provided in the problem statement.*Note:: I used blue boxes here as placeholders indicating original text content inserted before/after Step 2 above. To solve this problem, we need to simplify the arithmetic involved in finding the sum of the sequence $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199$ and take its modulo $7$. Let's break down the solution step by step.

Step 1: Recognize pattern
Noticing that every second term in the sequence starts with $1,$ we see that most elements come from adding consecutive prime numbers starting from $2$: ${1}+{2}+{3}+{5}+{7}+\cdots$. Every even position contains twice any prime minus $1$: $2*{p}-1$ being also always equal to half next primes (${p}'$). For example, since $4!=24$ equals three times six ($3 \times 6$), similarly $7!\equiv 1 (\mod 7)$, meaning every value except those whose representation would consist entirely of sevens appears once among eight successive natural numbers counting forward along unbroken lines parallel to base line segments drawn connecting adjacent dots arranged according to rule shown below right side picture [See Image]. Consequently because multiplying alternating single symbols followed leftmost symbol makes valid representations possible but cannot

0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

1.subquestion: Write down every term as either zero or some positive integer less than seven (exclusive), according to its congruence class modulo seven.

subanswer.text: Each term increases by five; thus they form pairs whose remainders add up to six ($1+2=3,$ etc.). There were thirty terms total, so half contribute nothing while the other fifty have remainders equal to three times their position in sequence divided by ten plus one ($\lfloor n/10\rfloor$), where floor means rounding towards negative infinity (\(\lfloor n/10\rfloor\) denotes how many groups of ten fit inside \(n\).): \[\begin{array}{|c|c|}\hline Position & Remainder \\ \hline k\text{(odd)} & \{\\[\frac{k}{2}+1\mod7\} \\ \hline k\text{(even)} & \{3\{k/10\}\mod7\} \\ \hline Total \;sum &= 3\;S_{25}+\underbrace{3*1}_{i=1}^{25}(3k/10)\equiv3*\frac {25*(25+1)*2*7}{4!}=\boxed{3} \pmod 7 . \end{array}\] The answer is $\{3\}$, which equals $[3]$. Note also that since $7^{2}-1=48<25\times 10=250,$ no residue repeats itself twice within any pairwise combination over those thirty integers – hence why I had trouble writing them without fractions..

2.subquestion: What does the notation \(\lfloor n/10\rfloor\) mean?

subanswer.text: It indicates the greatest integer not exceeding \(n/10\). In our case here at least because we're dealing wth multiples... 0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. Notice that each term in the sequence is congruent to either 1, 3, or -1 when taken modulo $7$, because adding multiples of 7 does not change the residue class under modulus $7$. For example, any odd multiple of $7$ such as $14k+7$, reduces to just $7 \equiv 0\pmod{7}$, so those terms don't contribute to our sum. Thus the problem simplifies to finding the sum $S=1+3+5-1-3-5+\dots+195+197+199$ which again takes alternating signs due to every other member being equivalent to zero mod $7$. Now notice how it would take us less work counting pairs since within each pair one value equals halfway around the clock compared to another; i.e., starting with ones side of midnight ($1$), ending up directly opposite at three o’clock (`+/- 2`) , going backwards along twelve hours until arriving back next day `$-\dfrac{N}{2}= -\dfrac{301}{2} \approx -151` . 0.user_question: Find the modulo $7$ remainder of the sum $1+3+5+7+9+\dots+195+197+199.$

1.subquestion: Observe that every third term starting at $1$ (i.e., terms whose index leaves a remainder of $1$ upon division by $3$) sums up to multiples of which prime?

subanswer.text: Every three consecutive integers form an arithmetic sequence where the middle term ($k+1$) equals their average. Hence they sum to $3(k+1)$. Consider only those cases such as our series have either no remainders or just ones after being divided by $3$; since adding together elements with different residues keeps you away from having zero 0.user_question: Given a list of conditions, please answer the question. Condition 1:  Calculate the arithmetic series starting from $1$ up to $199$ inclusive, considering only odd integers ($1$, $3$, $5$, etc.). Condition 2: Sum all terms obtained from Condition 1 together. Condition 3: When finding the resultant total mentioned in Condition 2, determine its equivalence class under Modulo $7$ operation. Question: What is the final quotient when dividing the summation calculated in Condition 2 by $7$? Note: Return just the residue without writing 'mod', providing whole numbers greater than or equal to zero exclusively.
